text: We'll hear argument now in No. 91-1421, United States against William F. Hill.
Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
When did Congress enact the minimum tax?
The first version of the minimum tax was enacted in 1969.
Thank you.
Yes.
And by virtue of the most recent change, I guess no minimum tax will be applied to this.

Under section 1915 of the Energy Policy Act of 1992, which was enacted 2 weeks ago, Congress has exempted the restricted minimum... I'm sorry... percentage depletion allowance for independent oil producers from the coverage of the minimum tax.
Well, that certainly indicates that at least the present Congress isn't viewing the situation quite like you do.
Actually what we think and what I believe the statute reflects is that there are two ways to attack abusive tax preferences.
Well, Mr. Jones, since I have you interrupted, may I ask one other question?
Well, we address it in the sense that all that regulation does is refer the reader to section 1016 of the code for adjustments to basis.
Well, but this regulation 1.57 at least can be read to mean that the special rule referred to in the regulation 1.612 doesn't apply.
--Well, there's--
And so, I just wondered why you didn't even talk about it.
--There's at least two reasons why that regulation has no relevance to the Court's decision in this case.
Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
As distinguished from the cost of drilling the well in the first place?
Your Honor, I think they both help in terms of producing them, but yes, they are distinguished from drilling the well in the first place.
And drilling the well is in your view an intangible.
Drilling the well is an intangible cost.
Well, are you depreciating any tangible property in connection with this mineral enterprise?
Your Honor, we are depreciating the tangible improvements to the mineral deposit.
You're taking a depreciation deduction.
--A depreciation deduction for the tangible improvements.
And not including that for purposes of figuring your depletion.
We are not including it for purposes of figuring our depletion.
So what kind of... what kind of property are you depreciating?
We're depreciating the casing that goes down into the well, the pump that brings the oil and gas to the surface.
And you're not including that in your... figuring your depletion.
No, we're not.
Well, without those properties, you wouldn't have much of an oil well either.
We couldn't.
Well, I thought you said that you were... the casing... are you including that in your... your basis for the depletion?
Not for depletion, Your Honor.
Even though it's absolutely essential for... to get the oil out of the ground.
Any costs that are represented by physical property have to be recovered through depreciation.
Well, now, tell me again.
It is the casing, the pipes, and the pumps that are lifting the oil and gas out of the ground.
Thank you.
Of course, that case didn't deal with the tax on the depletion allowance.
Well, it certainly doesn't involve the minimum tax.
